chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Next, we will talk about two special attributes in tables.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: One is called call span and the other is called row span.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: If we explain it in more detail, then it is column span and row span.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: When we understand the meaning of span here,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then we have to see how much area is surrounded by span.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: That is, how much area is occupied by a cell in a table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Usually, when I create a normal table, like this table,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then I can say that it occupies one row and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: That is, if we see it this way, then how many columns does a fruity cell come in?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: It comes in one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: If we see it this way, then how many rows does a fruity cell come in?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: It comes in one row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: If I talk about item, then it also occupies one row and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So whenever we write data in tables,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then by default, any cell occupies one row and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But sometimes I need to create tables in which a particular cell spans multiple columns or rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: In that case, we use these two attributes.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: For example, if I take the example of this table,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then I can see that the fruity cell occupies one column and one row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: My 10 cell also occupies one row and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But if I look at this price cell,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then if we look at the price cell, then it comes in one row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But if we look at the price cell, then it has two columns internally.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: This is one column and this is my second column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So the price is occupying two columns in one way.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So if I talk about the price cell,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then it occupies one row and two columns.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Similarly, if I talk about the item cell,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then the item cell occupies one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: That is, there is only one single line in the vertical line that can pass all the data across the table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But if I talk about rows, then I have to draw two lines in a row to cover the entire cell.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So the item is occupying two rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So let's write this once too that in my item cell,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have two rows and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So wherever there is one column, there is one row,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I don't have to do anything for this because by default, one cell will take one row and one column.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But if I have to give more rows and columns than this,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: like if I have to give two columns to the price,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then I will use the call span attribute and set the value to 2.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: By default, this value is always 1.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But when I write the call span and create the price header,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that is, when I write TH in this way,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and I am going to display the price in it,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then I have to use an attribute in TH which is equal to call span.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Here I will write call span equal to 2.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So in this way, the price will take one row by default,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: but how many columns will it take? It will take equal to two columns.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So then it will spread across two columns.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Similarly, if I have to talk about the item,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: then when I write the item, I will write TH

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and for this I am going to set the value of my row span equal to 2.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And here we will write item TH.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So in this way, when I write the item, it will be this big in size

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and if I write the price, it will be this big in size.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So if summarized, then column span and row span are attributes

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and with the help of these attributes, we create cells

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that surround or span multiple rows and multiple columns.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So with the help of these attributes, we are going to recreate this table a little.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: To recreate, let's understand what is going on inside this table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First of all, I can see that it is fixed here that this is the caption of my table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: The caption is food menu.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now what has changed inside the table?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First, the items are written as they were written,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: but this time the price is not only in rupees.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Here the price is in rupees, i.e. Indian Rupee INR

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and here the price is in US dollars.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I have given the title of USD and this is the title of INR.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So if you want, you can buy the same item in Indian Rupee or in US Dollar.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: We will recreate this table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First of all, let's talk about what is the header here.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's separate the header and main body.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: This is my header and this is my main body.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now if we talk about row wise,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I know that this is my one row and this is my second row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So inside the header, I know that I have to create two rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: With the help of which tag will we do?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: With the help of the TR tag.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: If we talk about the main body, then the main body is very simple.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But this time there is a small change

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that inside one row, what used to happen before?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: We used to create two data cells,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that is, we used to create two columns.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: This time we will be creating three columns in every row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So this is going to be very simple.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: We will create it row wise,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: in which my TR tag will be outside

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and my TD tag will be on the inside.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First of all, let's do the easy part.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: That is, let's create our caption first

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and create its body.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: We will not touch the header for now.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So what I will do is

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I am going to create a new table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's write the caption of the table first.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Caption is going to be

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Food Menu.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's delete the table above

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: because we are going to recreate this table again.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First of all, I know that

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have to create the header of my table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So for now we will leave it empty

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and I have to create the body of my table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: To create the body,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I will have to create three rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So this is my first row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now inside the first row, I have to create three cells.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I will display three types of data.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First, I am going to display Fruity.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: After that,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: we are going to display on the second number

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: its price in Indian Rupees which is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And after that,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: we are going to display its price in US Dollars

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: which is equal to 0.14.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I have created

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: one row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Similarly, I will create two more rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's change our item.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Samosa, 12 rupees,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Here I will display chips.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: 20 rupees,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's save it.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And here I have refreshed.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So the food menu is displayed

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and I have the complete data of my table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now the remaining work is to create the header.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: To create the header,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: for simplicity,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I am going to display

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: the border of my table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So that we can understand

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: what is going on inside the table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I have created a table

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: which has three columns in a single row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now let's create the header.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: To create the header,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I had understood that I have to create two rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So first of all,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: let's create the first row with the TR tag.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And then I have created the second row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I have used two TR tags.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now in the first row,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have to see which items are coming.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's remove all these things from the table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: In the first row,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I can see by drawing a horizontal line

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that one item is coming in the first row

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and the other is the price.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So I am going to write these things

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: with the help of two header tags.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: One will be my item and the other will be my price.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So here I will write

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: in the first row,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: my first header tag,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: which will have the item

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and then the second tag,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: which will have my price.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But one thing that we have understood

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: with the help of call span and row span

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: is that what is going to happen inside the item.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: The value of the row span is going to be 2

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: because how many rows does it occupy?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: It occupies 2 rows by default.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And the value of the call span

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: is going to be 2 in the price

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: because how many columns does it occupy?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: It occupies 2 columns because it can

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: produce 2 vertical lines.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: How can we understand how many columns are being occupied?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: The number of vertical lines that can come out

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: covering the entire table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: And how do we know how many rows are being occupied?

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: How many horizontal lines can come out

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: covering the entire table.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So for the item,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: we will write the value of the row span

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: as row span equals to 2

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and for the price, we will write

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: column span equals to 2.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Let's save this and for now

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: the table that we will see is something like this.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: In which we can see only the item

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and only the price.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But as soon as I create 2 more headers

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: in the second row,

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: let's talk about the second row.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: In the second row, I have

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: 3 items like this.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: One is Indian Rupees and the other is USD.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have these 3 headers available.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have already written the item

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: in the first row. It will just spread

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and come to the second row. So I will leave it empty.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: What I will do is I will create

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: only 2 elements.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: First is going to be INR header

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and second is going to be USD header.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So let's create

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: 2 headers here. First one will be INR

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and the second one will be

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: USD.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Now let's save this

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and refresh.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: So my table is looking exactly like the one we started with.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Here we can see in detail

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: that I have created the item

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: in the table in the code only once.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: But because I have used the row span attribute

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: with it, it has spread to 2 rows.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have created the price

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: only once but because

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: I have given 2 values to the call span

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: so it has spread to 2 columns

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: and the item has spread

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: to 2 rows. So in this way

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: we use the call span and row span attribute.

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: Whenever we want

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: a particular cell to reach multiple rows

chunks.title: Rowspan Attributes
chunks.text: or multiple columns.

text: Next, we will talk about two special attributes in tables. One is called call span and the other is called row span. If we explain it in more detail, then it is column span and row span. When we understand the meaning of span here, then we have to see how much area is surrounded by span. That is, how much area is occupied by a cell in a table. Usually, when I create a normal table, like this table, then I can say that it occupies one row and one column. That is, if we see it this way, then how many columns does a fruity cell come in? It comes in one column. If we see it this way, then how many rows does a fruity cell come in? It comes in one row. If I talk about item, then it also occupies one row and one column. So whenever we write data in tables, then by default, any cell occupies one row and one column. But sometimes I need to create tables in which a particular cell spans multiple columns or rows. In that case, we use these two attributes. For example, if I take the example of this table, then I can see that the fruity cell occupies one column and one row. My 10 cell also occupies one row and one column. But if I look at this price cell, then if we look at the price cell, then it comes in one row. But if we look at the price cell, then it has two columns internally. This is one column and this is my second column. So the price is occupying two columns in one way. So if I talk about the price cell, then it occupies one row and two columns. Similarly, if I talk about the item cell, then the item cell occupies one column. That is, there is only one single line in the vertical line that can pass all the data across the table. But if I talk about rows, then I have to draw two lines in a row to cover the entire cell. So the item is occupying two rows. So let's write this once too that in my item cell, I have two rows and one column. So wherever there is one column, there is one row, I don't have to do anything for this because by default, one cell will take one row and one column. But if I have to give more rows and columns than this, like if I have to give two columns to the price, then I will use the call span attribute and set the value to 2. By default, this value is always 1. But when I write the call span and create the price header, that is, when I write TH in this way, and I am going to display the price in it, then I have to use an attribute in TH which is equal to call span. Here I will write call span equal to 2. So in this way, the price will take one row by default, but how many columns will it take? It will take equal to two columns. So then it will spread across two columns. Similarly, if I have to talk about the item, then when I write the item, I will write TH and for this I am going to set the value of my row span equal to 2. And here we will write item TH. So in this way, when I write the item, it will be this big in size and if I write the price, it will be this big in size. So if summarized, then column span and row span are attributes and with the help of these attributes, we create cells that surround or span multiple rows and multiple columns. So with the help of these attributes, we are going to recreate this table a little. To recreate, let's understand what is going on inside this table. First of all, I can see that it is fixed here that this is the caption of my table. The caption is food menu. Now what has changed inside the table? First, the items are written as they were written, but this time the price is not only in rupees. Here the price is in rupees, i.e. Indian Rupee INR and here the price is in US dollars. So I have given the title of USD and this is the title of INR. So if you want, you can buy the same item in Indian Rupee or in US Dollar. We will recreate this table. First of all, let's talk about what is the header here. Let's separate the header and main body. This is my header and this is my main body. Now if we talk about row wise, I know that this is my one row and this is my second row. So inside the header, I know that I have to create two rows. With the help of which tag will we do? With the help of the TR tag. If we talk about the main body, then the main body is very simple. But this time there is a small change that inside one row, what used to happen before? We used to create two data cells, that is, we used to create two columns. This time we will be creating three columns in every row. So this is going to be very simple. We will create it row wise, in which my TR tag will be outside and my TD tag will be on the inside. First of all, let's do the easy part. That is, let's create our caption first and create its body. We will not touch the header for now. So what I will do is I am going to create a new table. Let's write the caption of the table first. Caption is going to be Food Menu. Let's delete the table above because we are going to recreate this table again. First of all, I know that I have to create the header of my table. So for now we will leave it empty and I have to create the body of my table. To create the body, I will have to create three rows. So this is my first row. Now inside the first row, I have to create three cells. So I will display three types of data. First, I am going to display Fruity. After that, we are going to display on the second number its price in Indian Rupees which is equal to 10. And after that, we are going to display its price in US Dollars which is equal to 0.14. So I have created one row. Similarly, I will create two more rows. Let's change our item. Samosa, 12 rupees, 0.17. Here I will display chips. 20 rupees, 0.28. Let's save it. And here I have refreshed. So the food menu is displayed and I have the complete data of my table. Now the remaining work is to create the header. To create the header, for simplicity, I am going to display the border of my table. So that we can understand what is going on inside the table. So I have created a table which has three columns in a single row. Now let's create the header. To create the header, I had understood that I have to create two rows. So first of all, let's create the first row with the TR tag. And then I have created the second row. So I have used two TR tags. Now in the first row, I have to see which items are coming. Let's remove all these things from the table. In the first row, I can see by drawing a horizontal line that one item is coming in the first row and the other is the price. So I am going to write these things with the help of two header tags. One will be my item and the other will be my price. So here I will write in the first row, my first header tag, which will have the item and then the second tag, which will have my price. But one thing that we have understood with the help of call span and row span is that what is going to happen inside the item. The value of the row span is going to be 2 because how many rows does it occupy? It occupies 2 rows by default. And the value of the call span is going to be 2 in the price because how many columns does it occupy? It occupies 2 columns because it can produce 2 vertical lines. How can we understand how many columns are being occupied? The number of vertical lines that can come out covering the entire table. And how do we know how many rows are being occupied? How many horizontal lines can come out covering the entire table. So for the item, we will write the value of the row span as row span equals to 2 and for the price, we will write column span equals to 2. Let's save this and for now the table that we will see is something like this. In which we can see only the item and only the price. But as soon as I create 2 more headers in the second row, let's talk about the second row. In the second row, I have 3 items like this. One is Indian Rupees and the other is USD. I have these 3 headers available. I have already written the item in the first row. It will just spread and come to the second row. So I will leave it empty. What I will do is I will create only 2 elements. First is going to be INR header and second is going to be USD header. So let's create 2 headers here. First one will be INR and the second one will be USD. Now let's save this and refresh. So my table is looking exactly like the one we started with. Here we can see in detail that I have created the item in the table in the code only once. But because I have used the row span attribute with it, it has spread to 2 rows. I have created the price only once but because I have given 2 values to the call span so it has spread to 2 columns and the item has spread to 2 rows. So in this way we use the call span and row span attribute. Whenever we want a particular cell to reach multiple rows or multiple columns.
